before_start: {"blocks":[{"key":"el37j","text":"To run this script command-line blastn and python 3 with packages pandas (v2.0.0), os, subprocess, argpase, re and biopython (v1.81) ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5e5mb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
description: {"blocks":[{"key":"cmpj2","text":"This protocol uses a python based script and command-line BLASTn to annotate in a final table single-read sequencing results from genome amplifications, within other output files.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"algh4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c2otn","text":"Its main use in our lab (https://biocomputationlab.com) is to identify the location and gene locus of transposon inserts in microbial bacterial genomes of Pseudomonas putida KT2440. However, this script can be used for other bacterial genomes for which its genome sequence and annotation are available.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":155,"length":25}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":25,"length":29}],"data":{}},{"key":"bofro","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1rtfq","text":"Script was developed and tested in python 3.9.5 with blastn version 2.9.0, sickle version 1.33 and fastqc version 0.11.9","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eqrhf","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9jjob","text":"This is a description of the LAP entry LAPu-InsertsGenAnnotation-1.0.0 located in the LAP repository","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":86,"length":14}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"21AC3C1F556711EDB33C0A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://biocomputationlab.com"}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"FFC5B8E64CAE48EFA104C332C048CE7B","url":"http://www.laprepo.com"}}}}
guidelines: {"blocks":[{"key":"c47e7","text":"This script needs min 4 arguments in the following order:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fkmhp","text":"Directory of folder containing sequencing reads","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"11rvi","text":"Reads file type (should be FASTA format even if the extension can be anything)","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cdsll","text":"Genome file to perform blastn alignment (FASTA format)","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4rfab","text":"Genome annotation file (.csv)","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"87fkr","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4ca72","text":"This program, by the time this guide was developed, can only be executed with Linux and macOS systems","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"c0eod","text":"Download reference genome file","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":30}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2v6ol","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b0p9u","text":"You can download the genome of the organism that you want to compare to the reading sequences from different sources such as NCBI, GSA or even pages dedicated to the organism (i.e pseudomonas.com).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8smss","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cecgd","text":"For this script to work, genome files need to be in FASTA format (.fasta, .fna, .ffn, .faa, .frn). Sequence alignment is based in BLASTn which requires FASTA format as input.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":52,"length":12},{"style":"bold","offset":152,"length":13}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

are other ways to run a Unix system in Windows, like a virtual machine https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/wsl/install","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":74,"length":53}],"data":{}},{"key":"90ubc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d5tam","text":"In the WSL, you can install the different requirements needed for the script to {"blocks":[{"key":"5732l","text":"Choose which arguments to run the script","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":40}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"48fvq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4net","text":"This script needs to be performed in a command line window using Python. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c2gsd","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7jhb3","text":"Depending on the provided arguments, the program will perform more or less actions such as a quality trimming or variant name annotation.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"mn47","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fq08","text":"The script requires a minimum of 4 arguments, which we will call from now on the positional arguments. In addition, the program's behaviour can be changed by providing optional arguments. Finally, there is another type of argument that the script can accept, which is for information usage.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":81,"length":20},{"style":"bold","offset":168,"length":18},{"style":"bold","offset":272,"length":17}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dgocv","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7203j","text":"In the following sub-steps, we will define the behaviour, needs and different kinds of arguments.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"1men9","text":"Annotation of sequencing results from P. putida KT2440 with only positional arguments","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":85},{"style":"italic","offset":38,"length":9},{"style":"italic","offset":48,"length":37}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"119dh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bl4b3","text":"This has been done in a Windows 10 with a WSL Ubuntu 20.04","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"2pi3d","text":"Download annotation file","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":24}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d11nt","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7s6o","text":"You can download the annotation of the genome from different sources, such as NCBI, KEGG or pages dedicated to the organism.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6kl5v","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fgo5j","text":"For this script to work, the annotation file needs to be in CSV format and need to have at least the following columns with the exact names (names in bold letter):","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":150,"length":11}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9gud","text":"Start - Nucleotide number that sets the beginning of the annotated region","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":5}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4t7c9","text":"End - Nucleotide number that sets the ending of the annotated region","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":3}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4paj7","text":"Locus Tag - Identifiers that are systematically applied to every gene in a genome. It has to be a unique name","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":9}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ekv0k","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"89vbt","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"43f1o","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eb54u","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"du8s5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":20,"offset":171,"style":"bold"}],"key":"7dqj9","text":"If the annotated file does not have those specific columns, but it has the information,the user can change the name of the columns to run the script because it should have exactly those names","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"d3vu8","text":"In case your annotated genome is not a CSV file but either a TSV, GFF or GTF, there are software that can convert those types of files to CSV:","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"2r8fh","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":53,"offset":106}],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":10,"offset":0,"style":"bold"},{"length":7,"offset":50,"style":"italic"},{"length":4,"offset":62,"style":"italic"}],"key":"aqmc5","text":"GFF to GFT: there are several convertors, such as gffread and AGAT. Some other converters can be found at https://agat.readthedocs.io/en/latest/gff_to_gtf.html","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"length":32,"offset":21}],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":10,"offset":0,"style":"bold"},{"length":7,"offset":12,"style":"italic"}],"key":"1rf1v","text":"GFT to CSV: gft2csv (https://github.com/zyxue/gtf2csv)","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":10,"offset":0,"style":"bold"},{"length":7,"offset":116,"style":"italic"}],"key":"e8jj9","text":"TSV to CSV: there are a lot of online converters and Python packages that you can use to convert TSV to CSV, such as pandas","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"9eikh","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":18,"offset":0,"style":"bold"},{"length":49,"offset":19,"style":"bold"},{"length":78,"offset":69,"style":"bold"}],"key":"6p9jc","text":"In future versions, those types of annotation files will be accepted, but at the time of development of this documentation only CSV files are valid","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"guid":"3A10F8FC8D4F11EEBD880A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://agat.readthedocs.io/en/latest/gff_to_gtf.html"},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"link"},"1":{"data":{"guid":"159D54558D4C11EEBD880A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://github.com/zyxue/gtf2csv"},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"link"}}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"7p51a","text":"Download sequencing files","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":25}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8963h","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"787qp","text":"Sequencing files should be contained in a folder. Depending on the sequencing company, sequencing files will be in .txt, .seq, .ab1 or other format. This should be specified within the script. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9iq94","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ct6v7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"65dl","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"ef5ni","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"bjaej","text":"The sequences that sequencing companies provide usually come with other files that give the quality of those reads. If we also have these files (.ab1, .fastqc, .abi, etc),  the user of this program will be able to produce results that are more trustworthy by providing these quality files to the script","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"528vo","text":"Optional: Acquisition of map of reads for annotation of variants","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":64}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4btqr","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2t1a9","text":"The identity of each variant can be annotated by using this script if a map of the 96-well plate is provided. It can be created by hand or can be an output file of other scripts, such as LAP-PCR-OT2-1.0.0.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":187,"length":17}],"data":{}},{"key":"6emrh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7lqkh","text":"This map should be a CSV file that will contain the names or identities of the plate that corresponds to the reads, for instance, the identities of the plate sent to sequence in the corresponding well. It needs to have the name of the rows and columns of the plate and can only be used if the reads and map fulfil the following requirements:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fahiu","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7mho2","text":"There is only 1 map","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":14,"length":5}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"v69m","text":"All the reads of the directory can be tracked in that map, i.e., the directory of reads should only include the ones in the map. An example, if the map has 12 columns and 8 rows and it is half full (48 identities), the directory of the reads cannot be more than 48 sequences.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":57}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9luqc","text":"All sequences need to have an identity in the map, i..e, the cell correspondent to a well in the map of a sequence cannot be left empty.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":49}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a6pau","text":"The names of the sequence files need to have the name of the cell between underscores if the extension of the reads is txt (for example, readSequence_A10_example.txt) or between a plus and an underscore if the extension is seq (for example, readSequence+A10_example.seq). Other types of extensions are not available with this function.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":66,"length":56},{"style":"bold","offset":170,"length":18},{"style":"bold","offset":189,"length":38},{"style":"italic","offset":137,"length":28},{"style":"italic","offset":241,"length":28}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2rgnu","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dfc1p","text":"An example of this script with the map provided will be given at the end of this page (section Example 2)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":105}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9i6ql","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"213DC3963E89434F931971FE0A675D82","url":"https://www.laprepo.cbgp.upm.es/repository/"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"an9ig","text":"Install BLAST+","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":14}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5n3sr","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a2bhr","text":"There are different ways to install BLAST, here we provide 3 ways in the substeps","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9noer","text":"Install FastQC","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":14}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cqrt3","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9d1kq","text":"FastQC is a tool used for quality control of high-throughput sequence data. {"blocks":[{"key":"1fskb","text":"Install Sickle","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":14}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6rjh2","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eut4f","text":"Sickle is a software tool designed for quality control of high-throughput sequence data, especially for data generated by Next-Generation Sequencing (NGS) platforms.
